videoInfo.description: The video analyzes a controversial conversation between Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin about human longevity and organ transplantation, which indirectly confirmed long-standing rumors about China's '981 project' and forced organ harvesting. It then delves into the 2012 '319 Incident' and the political downfall of Zhou Yongkang and Bo Xilai, linking their rise to power and the suppression of Falun Gong to the systemic growth of China's organ transplant industry.
videoInfo.summary: This video uncovers a 'big melon' sparked by a parade, revealing a conversation between Xi Jinping and Putin about achieving immortality through organ transplantation, confirming rumors about China's '981 Project' for leader longevity and the existence of forced organ harvesting. It further connects these revelations to the 2012 '319 Incident' and the political downfall of 'Political and Legal Affairs Czar' Zhou Yongkang and Bo Xilai, arguing their deep involvement in the organ transplant industry was a key motive in their power struggles. The analysis concludes that while these figures fell, the state-backed organ transplant industry, and its dark practices, have only grown stronger.

sections.title: The Xi-Putin Longevity Talk and Its Shocking Implications

content.content: A 2025 Beijing parade invited Putin and Kim Jong Un, where CCTV's live broadcast captured an unexpected conversation between Xi Jinping and Putin.
This footage, initially aired and then swiftly removed from Chinese internet, contained explosive chat about human longevity and organ transplantation.
Putin suggested organ transplants could lead to immortality, while Xi Jinping predicted humans could live to 150 by this century, referring to a specific group of people.
This conversation indirectly confirmed two long-circulating 'rumors' online regarding China's medical practices.

sections.title: The '981 Project' and Organ Harvesting Allegations

content.content: In 2019, an advertisement from the PLA General Hospital (301 Hospital) on WeChat revealed the '981 Project,' aimed at extending the lives of high-ranking CCP leaders to 150 years.
The ad, quickly blocked, detailed how 301 Hospital, a key healthcare provider for CCP leaders, had achieved an average lifespan of 88 for its leaders by 2008.
Former Cultural Minister Gao Zhanxiang's obituary, noting he had 'replaced many organs,' showcased how top officials benefit from extensive organ replacements.
The '981 Project' ad, which also offered services to wealthy elites, along with Xi Jinping's recent comments, validated the existence of this longevity program.
The discussion about organ transplantation leading to immortality strongly implies the necessity of live organ harvesting, given the low success rates for matching.
The large-scale existence of unexplained live organ transplants in China raises deep concerns about non-consensual harvesting, potentially involving murder.

sections.title: The 2012 '319 Incident': A Hidden Coup Attempt

content.content: These revelations also shed light on a decade-old hidden incident: the 2012 '319 Incident' or 'Xinhua Gate Incident,' involving powerful 'Political and Legal Affairs Czar' Zhou Yongkang.
On March 19, 2012, military vehicles and armed soldiers from the 38th Group Army entered Beijing, surrounding Xinhua Gate, the entrance to Zhongnanhai.
Reports indicated a standoff and warning shots between the 38th Army, loyal to Hu Jintao, and armed police, controlled by Zhou Yongkang, who was allegedly attempting a coup.
Public discussion and evidence of military presence and gunshots in Beijing were swiftly censored on Chinese social media.
International media, however, reported on the rumors of a coup and the resulting crackdown on online information.
The '319 Incident' followed a series of unusual political shifts, including Premier Wen Jiabao's public condemnation of Wang Lijun and the dismissal of Bo Xilai.
These events culminated in Zhou Yongkang's eventual downfall and life imprisonment for corruption, abuse of power, and leaking state secrets.

sections.title: Zhou Yongkang's Ascent, Power, and the Organ Trade

content.content: Zhou Yongkang, originally named Zhou Yuangen, began his career in the oil fields and rose through the ranks, eventually becoming a vice-minister of petroleum.
His career stalled until he allied with Jiang Zemin and Zeng Qinghong, leveraging the oil system as a platform for power and wealth.
He rapidly ascended, becoming Minister of Public Security and later the Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission Secretary, a position of immense power.
This coincided with the CCP's crackdown on Falun Gong in 1999, after which China's organ transplant centers dramatically increased from 22 to over 500 by 2005.
The 301 Hospital, which didn't have an organ transplant center before 1999, claimed to perform 5-8 transplants daily by 2016, indicating a vast organ supply and advanced techniques.

Allegations of forced organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners, first exposed in 2006, were facilitated by the extensive control of the Political and Legal Affairs Commission under Zhou Yongkang.
Zhou Yongkang's 'stability maintenance' system, commanding police, intelligence, and paramilitary forces, created an iron curtain, allowing these crimes to occur largely unnoticed.
China's 'stability maintenance' budget under Zhou Yongkang surpassed its defense budget by 2011, highlighting the state's focus on internal control.
Zhou Yongkang amassed enormous wealth through his control over the oil system and other resources, while the武警 (armed police) hospitals and prison systems provided a supply chain for organs.

sections.title: The Bo-Zhou Alliance and the Perpetuation of Organ Trafficking

content.content: Bo Xilai, another key figure, actively participated in suppressing Falun Gong as mayor of Dalian and governor of Liaoning, expanding prisons to detain practitioners, many of whom are believed to have become organ harvesting victims.
Zhou Yongkang, facing retirement due to age limits, sought to extend his influence by backing Bo Xilai for his Political and Legal Affairs Commission secretary position, forming a political alliance.
The Wang Lijun incident in 2012, where Bo Xilai's police chief fled to the US consulate, exposed their deep political struggles and plans.
Despite overwhelming opposition from other Politburo Standing Committee members, Zhou Yongkang staunchly supported Bo Xilai, suggesting a deeper, shared motive.
A leaked conversation revealed Bo and Zhou's ambitious plan to 'do something big,' indicating their intention to stage a coup.
The '319 Incident' was triggered when Beijing Public Security Bureau chief Fu Zhenghua betrayed Zhou Yongkang's plot to Hu Jintao, leading to the deployment of the 38th Group Army.

Zhou Yongkang's unwavering support for Bo Xilai, despite the risks, suggests their 'co-enterprise' in the lucrative and illicit organ transplant industry, which they feared would be exposed after Zhou's retirement.
Even after Zhou Yongkang's downfall, the organ transplant industry he and Bo Xilai fostered continued to flourish, shifting its focus from labor camps to a broader societal pool.

The disappearance of individuals like Hu Xinyu and widespread unexplained disappearances, coupled with the national collection of biometric data, indicate a sophisticated, state-backed system for organ matching and harvesting.
Today, China's organ transplant industry operates at an unprecedented scale with state endorsement, making the dream of living to 150 a grim reality for some at the expense of others.
